verses.verse: Then Job <S%H347><s%> answered <S%H6030><s%> and said <S%H559><s%>,
I know <S%H3045><s%> it is so of a truth <S%H551><s%>: but how should man <S%H582><s%> be just <S%H6663><s%> with God <S%H410><s%>? with God: or, before God?
If he will <S%H2654><s%> contend <S%H7378><s%> with him, he cannot answer <S%H6030><s%> him one <S%H259><s%> of a thousand <S%H505><s%>.
He is wise <S%H2450><s%> in heart <S%H3824><s%>, and mighty <S%H533><s%> in strength <S%H3581><s%>: who hath hardened <S%H7185><s%> himself against him, and hath prospered <S%H7999><s%>?
Which removeth <S%H6275><s%> the mountains <S%H2022><s%>, and they know <S%H3045><s%> not: which overturneth <S%H2015><s%> them in his anger <S%H639><s%>.
Which shaketh <S%H7264><s%> the earth <S%H776><s%> out of her place <S%H4725><s%>, and the pillars <S%H5982><s%> thereof tremble <S%H6426><s%>.
Which commandeth <S%H559><s%> the sun <S%H2775><s%>, and it riseth <S%H2224><s%> not; and sealeth up <S%H2856><s%> the stars <S%H3556><s%>.
Which alone spreadeth out <S%H5186><s%> the heavens <S%H8064><s%>, and treadeth <S%H1869><s%> upon the waves <S%H1116><s%> of the sea <S%H3220><s%>. waves: Heb. heights
Which maketh <S%H6213><s%> Arcturus <S%H5906><s%>, Orion <S%H3685><s%>, and Pleiades <S%H3598><s%>, and the chambers <S%H2315><s%> of the south <S%H8486><s%>. Arcturus: Heb. Ash, Cesil, and Cimah
Which doeth <S%H6213><s%> great things <S%H1419><s%> past <S%H369><s%> finding out <S%H2714><s%>; yea, and wonders <S%H6381><s%> without number <S%H4557><s%>.
Lo, he goeth <S%H5674><s%> by me, and I see <S%H7200><s%> him not: he passeth on <S%H2498><s%> also, but I perceive <S%H995><s%> him not.
Behold, he taketh away <S%H2862><s%>, who can hinder <S%H7725><s%> him? who will say <S%H559><s%> unto him, What doest <S%H6213><s%> thou? hinder: Heb. turn him away?
If God <S%H433><s%> will not withdraw <S%H7725><s%> his anger <S%H639><s%>, the proud <S%H7293><s%> helpers <S%H5826><s%> do stoop <S%H7817><s%> under him. proud: Heb. helpers of pride, or, strength
How much less shall I answer <S%H6030><s%> him, and choose out <S%H977><s%> my words <S%H1697><s%> to reason with him?
Whom, though I were righteous <S%H6663><s%>, yet would I not answer <S%H6030><s%>, but I would make supplication <S%H2603><s%> to my judge <S%H8199><s%>.
If I had called <S%H7121><s%>, and he had answered <S%H6030><s%> me; yet would I not believe <S%H539><s%> that he had hearkened <S%H238><s%> unto my voice <S%H6963><s%>.
For he breaketh <S%H7779><s%> me with a tempest <S%H8183><s%>, and multiplieth <S%H7235><s%> my wounds <S%H6482><s%> without cause <S%H2600><s%>.
He will not suffer <S%H5414><s%> me to take <S%H7725><s%> my breath <S%H7307><s%>, but filleth <S%H7646><s%> me with bitterness <S%H4472><s%>.
If I speak of strength <S%H3581><s%>, lo, he is strong <S%H533><s%>: and if of judgment <S%H4941><s%>, who shall set <S%H3259><s%> me a time to plead?
If I justify <S%H6663><s%> myself, mine own mouth <S%H6310><s%> shall condemn <S%H7561><s%> me: if I say, I am perfect <S%H8535><s%>, it shall also prove me perverse <S%H6140><s%>.
Though I were perfect <S%H8535><s%>, yet would I not know <S%H3045><s%> my soul <S%H5315><s%>: I would despise <S%H3988><s%> my life <S%H2416><s%>.
This is one <S%H259><s%> thing, therefore I said <S%H559><s%> it, He destroyeth <S%H3615><s%> the perfect <S%H8535><s%> and the wicked <S%H7563><s%>.
If the scourge <S%H7752><s%> slay <S%H4191><s%> suddenly <S%H6597><s%>, he will laugh <S%H3932><s%> at the trial <S%H4531><s%> of the innocent <S%H5355><s%>.

The earth <S%H776><s%> is given <S%H5414><s%> into the hand <S%H3027><s%> of the wicked <S%H7563><s%>: he covereth <S%H3680><s%> the faces <S%H6440><s%> of the judges <S%H8199><s%> thereof; if not, where <S%H645><s%>, and who is he?
Now my days <S%H3117><s%> are swifter <S%H7043><s%> than a post <S%H7323><s%>: they flee away <S%H1272><s%>, they see <S%H7200><s%> no good <S%H2896><s%>.

They are passed away <S%H2498><s%> as <S%H5973><s%> the swift <S%H16><s%> ships <S%H591><s%>: as the eagle <S%H5404><s%> that hasteth <S%H2907><s%> to the prey <S%H400><s%>. swift: or, ships of Ebeh: Heb. ships of desire
If I say <S%H559><s%>, I will forget <S%H7911><s%> my complaint <S%H7879><s%>, I will leave off <S%H5800><s%> my heaviness <S%H6440><s%>, and comfort <S%H1082><s%> myself:
I am afraid <S%H3025><s%> of all my sorrows <S%H6094><s%>, I know <S%H3045><s%> that thou wilt not hold me innocent <S%H5352><s%>.
If I be wicked <S%H7561><s%>, why then labour <S%H3021><s%> I in vain <S%H1892><s%>?
If I wash <S%H7364><s%> myself with <S%H7950><s%> snow water <S%H4325><s%> <S%H1119><s%>, and make my hands <S%H3709><s%> never <S%H1252><s%> <S%H1253><s%> so clean <S%H2141><s%>;
Yet <S%H227><s%> shalt thou plunge <S%H2881><s%> me in the ditch <S%H7845><s%>, and mine own clothes <S%H8008><s%> shall abhor <S%H8581><s%> me. abhor: or, make me to be abhorred
For he is not a man <S%H376><s%>, as I am, that I should answer <S%H6030><s%> him, and we should come <S%H935><s%> together <S%H3162><s%> in judgment <S%H4941><s%>.

Neither is <S%H3426><s%> there any daysman <S%H3198><s%> betwixt us, that might lay <S%H7896><s%> his hand <S%H3027><s%> upon us both <S%H8147><s%>. any: Heb. one that should argue daysman: or, umpire
Let him take <S%H5493><s%> his rod <S%H7626><s%> away <S%H5493><s%> from me, and let not his fear <S%H367><s%> terrify <S%H1204><s%> me:
Then would I speak <S%H1696><s%>, and not fear <S%H3372><s%> him; but it is not so with me. it is: Heb. I am not so with myself
